title.narrative: Färdplan för kvinnors politiska deltagande i 2016
Roadmap on Women's Political Participation in 2016

description.narrative: Percentage of women voted for at parliamentary and local levels in intervention districts increased to 30%

Kvinnors deltagande i politiken och generellt i beslutsfattande positioner i Zambia är fortsatt lågt trots att landet undertecknat och ratificerat ett antal internationella och regionala kandiderar protokoll och konventioner. Trots att kvinnor utgör majoriteten av Zambias befolkning är antalet kvinnor och väljs till politiska- och ledandepositioner, särskilt hos lokal förvaltning och parlamentet, fortfarande lågt i förhållande till män. Av de 158 parlamentsplatserna har endast 24 platser (15%) gått till kvinnor, och ytterligare 86 platser (6%) av 1422 på kommunal nivå, har gått till kvinnor. Zambia har misslyckats med att uppfylla Afrikanska unionen (AU) och SADC mål om att kvinnors deltagande och representation i beslutsfattande positioner, ska uppgå till 30 respektive 50 procent. Utmaningarna för kvinnors deltagande i politiska processer inkluderar negativa attityder och praxis hos politiska partier och bland den allmänna väljarkåren, begränsade resurser för kampanj och patriarkala system och strukturer, seder och traditioner. Detta bidrar i hög grad till att kvinnor avskräcks från att delta i politiska processer.
Insatsen syftar till att öka kvinnors deltagande under valet 2016 genom en mer samordnad strategi för organisationer som arbetar med kvinnors politiska deltagande. Mer konkret förväntas insatsen öka och förbättra kvinnors deltagande genom; - Samordna civila samhällets organisationer för att öka den geografiska täckningen av interventioner och minska duplicering; säkerställa koalitionsuppbyggnad och arbeta för gemensam opinionsbildning. - Stärkt kapacitet hos blivande kvinnliga kandidater att tala inför publik och kampanjarbete - Att engagera en kritisk massa av det civila samhällets organisationer (CSO), och andra likasinnade aktörer att genomföra kampanjer för att visa på vikten av att rösta in kvinnor i politiken och stödja kvinnor under nomineringar och under lansering av kampanjer - Offentliga kampanjer och mobilisering genom information, kommunikation och teknik (ICT), såsom sociala medier, tv och närradioprogram för att stödja kvinnors deltagande i politiken; bygga kapacitet hos media för att rapportera om den positiva roll som kvinnors kandidatur utgör i politiken; påverka traditionella- och religiösa ledare att stödja kvinnors deltagande i politiken och skapa en dialog med män och pojkar som förändringsagenter för att stödja kvinnor i politiken.
Avsikten är att insatsen ska bidra till att höja andelen kvinnor som väljs på kommunnivå från 6% till 30% och från 15% till 30% på parlamentsnivå.
The participation of women in politics and generally in decision-making positions in Zambia, continue to be low despite the country signing and ratifying a number of international and regional protocols and conventions. Despite the fact that women constitute the majority of Zambia’s total population, the number of women vying and elected for political positions and leadership, particularly at local government as Councilors and at Parliamentary level, remains low in comparison to those of the men folk. Currently, out of the 158 parliamentary seats, only 24 seats (15%), and a further 86 seats (6%) out of 1422 at Local Government level, have gone to women. Zambia has failed to meet the African Union (AU) and SADC threshold of 30 percent and 50 percent respectively on women’s participation and representation in decision making positions. The challenges to women's participation in political processes include negative attitudes and practices in political parties and among the general electorate, limited resources for campaigning and patriarchal systems and structures, tradition and customs. These largely discourage women from participating
The intervention seeks to increase the participation of women in the 2016 general elections in Zambia through a more coordinated approach of organisations working on women's political participation. Specifically, the intervention is intended to increase and enhance women's participation through the following ways: - Coordinating of civil society organisations to increase geographical coverage of interventions and reduce duplication; to ensure coalition building and facilitate joint advocacy. - Buidling the capacity of aspiring women candidates for public speaking and campaigning. - Building a critical mass of civil society organisations (CSOs) and other like-minded stakeholders to carry out campaigns on importance of voting for women in politics and carrying out solidarity matches for women when they are filing in nominations and launching campaigns - Public Campaigns and mobilisation through using Information, Communication and Technology (ICT) such as social media , television and community radio programmes to support women’s participation in politics; building capacities of media professionals to report on the positive role of women candidature in politics; Lobbying traditional and church leaders to support the positive role of women in politics and engagement and dialogue with men and boys in different communities as change agents on supporting women in politics.
It is intended that the intervention will contribute to raising the percentage of women elected at local governemnt level from 6% to 30% and from 15% to 30% at parliamentary level.

The intervention is a coordinated approach to enhancing women's political participation in the 2016 general elections. The focus will include coordinating civil society organisations, public campaigns and community mobilisation as well as capacity building of current and aspiring candidates.

description.narrative: The operational objectives of the intervention were to coordinate CSOs promoting women in politics effectively; build the capacities of women aspirants in leadership and campaign skills at parliamentary and local levels; mobilise a critical mass of CSOs and other like-minded stakeholders to carry out campaigns on the importance of voting for women in politics; and raise public awareness on the importance of voting for women. An evaluation of the intervention established that the intervention was useful in increasing the likelihood of an aspirant being validly nominated and vote for. Activities observed to have had most impact were the Women’s Development Dialogues, training of female electoral aspirants, election materials provision, door-to-door campaigns, voter sensitization in the wards and engagement with traditional and religious leaders. In summary, the intervention was able to mobilise female aspiring candidates as well as engage the media, traditional and other leaders, political parties as well as young people on the importance of voting for women. An unexpected turn of events, which is believed to have had a negative impact on the number of women nominated and voted for was the requirement of a grade 12 certificate (secondary school certificate) for candidates.This disadvantaged many women who did not have this level of education. The violence that characterised the 2016 elections is said to have also discouraged women from participating effectively.
